title: C. J. Mosley (linebacker)
text:
Clint Mosley Jr. (born June 19, 1992) is an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a> for the <a href="New%20York%20Jets">New York Jets</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL). He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20football">Alabama</a>, and was drafted by the <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a> in the first round of the <a href="2014%20NFL%20Draft">2014 NFL Draft</a>.
High school career.
A native of <a href="Theodore%2C%20Alabama">Theodore, Alabama</a>, Mosley attended <a href="Theodore%20High%20School">Theodore High School</a>, where he played <a href="high%20school%20football">football</a>, <a href="high%20school%20basketball">basketball</a>, and ran <a href="track%20and%20field">track</a>. As a sophomore, he was credited with 112 tackles, four sacks, and one interception, as the Bobcats finished with a 6–5 record, losing to <a href="Auburn%20High%20School%20Tigers">Auburn</a> in the opening round of the Class 6A playoffs. In his junior season, Mosley set a school record with 176 tackles, (115 solo), while also recording 17 tackles for loss, seven sacks, causing four fumbles, recovering two more, and intercepting two passes, earning an ASWA 6A All-State selection.
Improving his own school record, Mosley registered 186 tackles as a senior in 2009, also adding seven sacks, five fumble recoveries, and four interceptions. Theodore finished with a 9–2 season record, yet was upset by future Alabama teammate <a href="T.%20J.%20Yeldon">T. J. Yeldon</a>'s <a href="Daphne%20High%20School">Daphne</a> team in the first round of the playoffs. Still, Mosley earned his second consecutive ASWA 6A All-State honors, as well as Class 6A Lineman of the Year. He finished his career at Theodore as the school's all-time leading tackler, with over 500 stops in his career.
In addition, Mosley was on the school's <a href="track%20%26amp%3B%20field">track & field</a> team. He ran the <a href="110%20metres%20hurdles">110m hurdles</a> in 16.15 seconds and the <a href="200%20meters">200m dash</a> in 24.33 seconds. In the jumping events, he got personal-best leaps of 1.80 meters in the <a href="high%20jump">high jump</a>, 6.58 meters in the <a href="long%20jump">long jump</a> and 12.6 meters in the <a href="triple%20jump">triple jump</a>. He was also a member of the <a href="4%20x%20100%20metres%20relay">4 × 100 m relay</a> (43.44 s) squad.
Regarded as a four-star recruit by the <a href="Rivals.com">Rivals.com</a> recruiting network, Mosley was listed as the sixth-ranked outside linebacker prospect in a class highlighted by five-star linebackers <a href="Jordan%20Hicks">Jordan Hicks</a> and <a href="Christian%20Jones%20%28American%20football%29">Christian Jones</a>. He was also the second-ranked player from Alabama, behind fellow Crimson Tide recruit <a href="Dee%20Milliner">Dee Milliner</a>. Mosley played in the 2010 <a href="U.S.%20Army%20All-American%20Bowl">U.S. Army All-American Bowl</a>, where he committed to Alabama during the game. He chose the Crimson Tide over <a href="Auburn%20Tigers%20football">Auburn</a>, but also had offers from <a href="Florida%20State%20Seminoles%20football">Florida State</a>, <a href="Oklahoma%20Sooners%20football">Oklahoma</a>, and <a href="Tennessee%20Volunteers%20football">Tennessee</a>, among others.
College career.
Freshman year (2010).
Mosley was a consensus Freshman All-American in 2010 for the Crimson Tide, selected by the <a href="Football%20Writers%20Association%20of%20America">FWAA</a>, <a href="Rivals.com">Rivals.com</a>, and <a href="College%20Football%20News">College Football News</a> after playing in all 13 games as a true <a href="Freshman%23United%20States">freshman</a>.
Sophomore year (2011).
Mosley dislocated his right elbow in the first quarter of the fourth game of the 2011 season against <a href="2011%20Arkansas%20Razorbacks%20football%20team">Arkansas</a>. He missed the following two games against <a href="2011%20Florida%20Gators%20football%20team">Florida</a> and <a href="2011%20Vanderbilt%20Commodores%20football%20team">Vanderbilt</a> and did not record a tackle in the next game against <a href="2011%20Ole%20Miss%20Rebels%20football%20team">Mississippi</a>. Mosley shared the starting weak-side inside linebacker ("Will") linebacker spot with <a href="Nico%20Johnson">Nico Johnson</a> in 2011 and 2012, with Alabama coaches using Mosley more in pass coverage.
Junior year (2012).
The <a href="Associated%20Press">Associated Press</a> recognized Mosley as a first team All-American after the 2012 regular season, a year after former teammate linebacker <a href="Dont%27a%20Hightower">Dont'a Hightower</a> made the AP All-American first team and other linebacker teammate <a href="Courtney%20Upshaw">Courtney Upshaw</a> made the second team. With Mosley's selection to the AP All-American team in 2012, Alabama had a linebacker on that team (first through third teams) for four of the previous five years. Mosley led the team in tackles in 2012 with 107; sophomore <a href="Trey%20DePriest">Trey DePriest</a> was second with 59 tackles. Mosley finished third for the 2012 Butkus Award (goes to the country's best linebacker) behind Notre Dame linebacker <a href="Manti%20Te%27o">Manti Te'o</a> and Georgia linebacker <a href="Jarvis%20Jones">Jarvis Jones</a>. Mosley earned Alabama's MVP award in 2012. Mosley's three career interception returns for touchdowns tied an Alabama record. Mosley indicated in December 2012 that he will return to Alabama for his <a href="2013%20Alabama%20Crimson%20Tide%20football%20team">senior season</a>.
Senior year (2013).
Mosley led the Alabama football team in tackles (108) for the second consecutive year, averaging the most tackles-per-game in his college career. In November 2013, Mosley was a semifinalist for the Lombardi, Bednarik and Butkus Awards. While the Missouri Tigers's Michael Sam is often remembered as the 2013 SEC Defensive Player of the Year, he and Mosley actually shared the award.
Mosley was again named as a first-team All-<a href="Southeastern%20Conference">Southeastern Conference</a> (SEC) selection. He was also selected to the First Team of the Associated Press' All-America Team.
Professional career.
Prior to the NFL Combine, Mosley underwent surgery to repair a labrum issue after dislocating his hip. He attended the NFL Scouting Combine in <a href="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>, but was not able to participate in running drills as he was still recovering. Mosley completed the vertical jump, short shuttle, three-cone drill, and broad jump at the combine.
On March 12, 2014, Mosley participated at Alabama's pro day and performed the 40-yard dash (4.63s), 20-yard dash (2.70s), 10-yard dash (1.56s), and bench press (15). Multiple NFL scouts and team representatives attended Alabama's pro day, including head coaches <a href="Sean%20Payton">Sean Payton</a> <a href="New%20Orleans%20Saints">(Saints)</a>, <a href="Marvin%20Lewis">Marvin Lewis</a> <a href="Cincinnati%20Bengals">(Bengals)</a>, and <a href="Chip%20Kelly">Chip Kelly</a> <a href="Philadelphia%20Eagles">(Eagles)</a>. At the conclusion of the pre-draft process, Mosley was projected to be a first round pick by NFL draft experts and scouts. He was regarded as a top 15 pick, but fell in some first round projections due to his lengthy injury history. Mosley attended pre-draft visits and private workouts for multiple teams, but received the most interest from the <a href="Buffalo%20Bills">Buffalo Bills</a> and Baltimore Ravens.
Baltimore Ravens.
2014.
The <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a> selected Mosley in the first round (17th overall) of the <a href="2014%20NFL%20Draft">2014 NFL Draft</a>. Mosley was the fourth linebacker drafted in 2014 and became the highest linebacker drafted from Alabama since <a href="Rolando%20McClain">Rolando McClain</a> went eighth overall in <a href="2010%20NFL%20Draft">2010</a>. In addition, he was one of eight Alabama Crimson Tide players to be selected that year.
On May 27, 2014, the Baltimore Ravens signed Mosley to a four-year, <a href="United%20States%20dollar">$</a>8.87 million contract that includes a <a href="signing%20bonus">signing bonus</a> of $4.71 million.
Mosley was assigned the No. 57, which was worn by former Baltimore Raven <a href="O.%20J.%20Brigance">O. J. Brigance</a>. The No. 57 had been unofficially retired after Brigance was diagnosed with <a href="Amyotrophic%20lateral%20sclerosis">ALS</a>. No. 57 was also worn by <a href="Bart%20Scott">Bart Scott</a> (who was assigned the number before O.J. Brigance's diagnosis). Head coach <a href="John%20Harbaugh">John Harbaugh</a> named Mosley and <a href="Daryl%20Smith%20%28linebacker%29">Daryl Smith</a> the starting inside linebackers to begin the regular season, alongside outside linebackers <a href="Courtney%20Upshaw">Courtney Upshaw</a> and <a href="Terrell%20Suggs">Terrell Suggs</a>. Mosley was the first rookie to start on the Ravens' defense since <a href="Haloti%20Ngata">Haloti Ngata</a> in <a href="2006%20NFL%20season">2006</a>.
He made his professional regular season debut and first career start in the <a href="2014%20Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens'</a> season-opener against the <a href="2014%20Cincinnati%20Bengals">Cincinnati Bengals</a> and made seven combined tackles and a pass deflection in their 23–16 loss. On October 5, 2014, Mosley collected a season-high 15 combined tackles (eight solo), deflected a pass, and made his first career interception during a 21–13 loss at the <a href="2014%20Indianapolis%20Colts">Indianapolis Colts</a> in Week 4. Mosley intercepted a pass by quarterback <a href="Andrew%20Luck">Andrew Luck</a>, off a tipped pass originally intended for running back <a href="Ahmad%20Bradshaw">Ahmad Bradshaw</a>, and returned it for an 18-yard gain in the fourth quarter. In Week 12 Mosley recorded nine solo tackles and made his first career sack on Saints' quarterback <a href="Drew%20Brees">Drew Brees</a> for a six-yard loss in the second quarter of the Ravens' 34–27 win at the <a href="2014%20New%20Orleans%20Saints">New Orleans Saints</a>. On December 23, 2014, it was announced that Mosley was selected to play in the <a href="2015%20Pro%20Bowl">2015 Pro Bowl</a>, making him the first Baltimore Ravens player to be voted to the Pro Bowl in their rookie season. Mosley was the runner-up for <a href="National%20Football%20League%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year%20Award">NFL Defensive Rookie of the Year</a>. He finished his rookie season in <a href="2014%20NFL%20season">2014</a> with 133 combined tackles (89 solo), eight pass deflections, three sacks, and two interceptions in 16 games and 16 starts.
The Baltimore Ravens finished third in the <a href="AFC%20North">AFC North</a> with a 10–6 record and earned a wildcard berth. On January 3, 2015, Mosley started his first career playoff game and recorded nine combined tackles during the Ravens' 30–17 win at the <a href="2014%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> in the AFC Wildcard Game. The following week, he made ten combined tackles (seven solo) and forced a fumble during a 35–31 loss at the <a href="2014%20New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a> in the AFC Divisional Round.
2015.
Head coach John Harbaugh retained Mosley and Daryl Smith as the starting inside linebackers to start the season, alongside outside linebackers <a href="Elvis%20Dumervil">Elvis Dumervil</a> and <a href="Terrell%20Suggs">Terrell Suggs</a>.
He started in the <a href="2015%20Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens'</a> season-opener at the <a href="2015%20Denver%20Broncos">Denver Broncos</a> and made six combined tackles, deflected a pass, and made two sacks on quarterback <a href="Peyton%20Manning">Peyton Manning</a> during a 19–13 loss. On September 27, 2015, Mosley recorded nine combined tackles, deflected a pass, and returned a fumble recovery for the first touchdown of his career during a 28–24 loss in Week 3. Mosley recovered a fumble after teammate Elvis Dumervil stripped the ball from quarterback <a href="Andy%20Dalton">Andy Dalton</a> and returned it for a 41-yard touchdown in the fourth quarter. On November 22, 2015, he collected a season-high 12 combined tackles (seven solo) during a 16–13 victory against the <a href="2015%20St.%20Louis%20Rams">St. Louis Rams</a> in Week 11. He started all 16 games in <a href="2015%20NFL%20season">2015</a> and recorded 117 combined tackles (77 solo), seven pass deflections, four sacks, a forced fumble, a fumble recovery, and a touchdown.
2016.
Defensive coordinator <a href="Dean%20Pees">Dean Pees</a> retained Mosley as a starting inside linebacker to begin the regular season, alongside <a href="Zach%20Orr">Zach Orr</a> and outside linebackers Terrell Suggs and Elvis Dumervil.
In Week 3, he recorded six combined tackles, broke up two passes, and made an interception during a 19–17 win at the <a href="2016%20Jacksonville%20Jaguars">Jacksonville Jaguars</a>. This marked his second consecutive game with an interception. Mosley was inactive for two games (Weeks 6–7) due to a <a href="hamstring">hamstring</a> injury. The injury ended his 37-game streak of consecutive starts. On December 18, 2016, Mosley collected a season-high 13 combined tackles (eight solo) during a 27–26 win against the <a href="2016%20Philadelphia%20Eagles">Philadelphia Eagles</a> in Week 15. On December 20, 2016, it was announced that Mosley was voted to the <a href="2017%20Pro%20Bowl">2017 Pro Bowl</a>, marking the second <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> selection of his career. and <a href="All-Pro">second-team All-Pro</a> He finished the <a href="2016%20NFL%20season">2016 season</a> with 92 combined tackles (56 solo), eight pass deflections, four interceptions, and a forced fumble in 14 games and 14 starts. Pro Football Focus gave Mosley an overall grade of 85.8. His grade was the 11th best grade among all qualifying linebackers in 2016.
2017.
On March 28, 2017, the Baltimore Ravens exercised the fifth-year option on Mosley's rookie contract. The option earned him a base salary of $8.71 million for the 2017 season. Head coach John Harbaugh named Mosley and <a href="Kamalei%20Correa">Kamalei Correa</a> the starting inside linebackers to begin the regular season, alongside outside linebackers <a href="Terrell%20Suggs">Terrell Suggs</a> and <a href="Matthew%20Judon">Matthew Judon</a>.
He started in the <a href="2017%20Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens'</a> season-opener at the <a href="2017%20Cincinnati%20Bengals%20season">Cincinnati Bengals</a> and recorded eight combined tackles, deflected a pass, and intercepted a pass by quarterback <a href="Andy%20Dalton">Andy Dalton</a> during a 20–0 victory. On October 26, 2017, Mosley made four combined tackles, a pass deflection, was credited with half a sack, and returned an interception for a touchdown during a 40–0 victory on "<a href="Thursday%20Night%20Football">Thursday Night Football</a>" against the <a href="2017%20Miami%20Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> in Week 8. Mosley intercepted a pass by Dolphins' quarterback <a href="Matt%20Moore%20%28American%20football%29">Matt Moore</a>, that was initially intended for wide receiver <a href="Jarvis%20Landry">Jarvis Landry</a>, and returned it for a 63-yard touchdown in the fourth quarter. The touchdown marked his first career <a href="Pick%206%20%28American%20football%29">pick six</a>. In Week 14, he collected a season-high 14 combined tackles (nine solo) and made a pass deflection in the Ravens' 39–38 loss at the <a href="2017%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>. On December 19, 2017, it was announced that Mosley was voted to the <a href="2018%20Pro%20Bowl">2018 Pro Bowl</a> which marked his third Pro Bowl selection of his career. He started in all 16 games in <a href="2017%20NFL%20season">2017</a> and recorded 132 combined tackles (96 solo), seven pass deflections, three forced fumbles, three fumble recoveries, two interceptions, one sack, and a touchdown. <a href="Pro%20Football%20Focus">Pro Football Focus</a> gave Mosley an overall grade of 72.6, which ranked 20th among all qualifying linebackers in 2017. He was ranked 98th by his peers on the <a href="NFL%20Top%20100%20Players%20of%202018">NFL Top 100 Players of 2018</a>.
2018.
On December 18, 2018, C.J Mosley was named to his 4th <a href="2019%20Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> of his career. On December 30, 2018, Mosley made 4.5 combined tackles (three solo) and a game-winning interception during a 26–24 victory against the <a href="Cleveland%20Browns">Cleveland Browns</a> in Week 17. Mosley intercepted a pass by Browns' quarterback <a href="Baker%20Mayfield">Baker Mayfield</a> intended for running back, <a href="Duke%20Johnson">Duke Johnson</a> at 1:06 of the fourth quarter, sealing the victory. The victory resulted in the Ravens clinching the <a href="AFC%20North">AFC North</a> division against the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> and a playoff spot with a 10–6 record. He finished the season as the Ravens leading tackler with 105 combined tackles, along with half a sack, five passes defensed, and an interception.
New York Jets.
On March 15, 2019, Mosley signed a five-year, $85 million deal with the <a href="New%20York%20Jets">New York Jets</a>. Mosley made his debut with the Jets in Week 1 against the <a href="2019%20Buffalo%20Bills%20season">Buffalo Bills</a>, making 5 tackles and intercepting a pass from quarterback <a href="Josh%20Allen%20%28quarterback%29">Josh Allen</a> and returning it for a touchdown. However, he injured his groin in the third quarter and did not return. Prior to his injury, the Jets held a 16–0 lead, but collapsed afterwards to lose 17–16. On December 3, the Jets placed Mosley on injured reserve due to an aggravating groin injury throughout the season. He was the 15th different player on the team to go on injured reserve. It was revealed that he needed groin surgery to repair the issue.
On August 3, 2020, Mosley announced he would opt out of the 2020 season due to the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>.
